text: Keg at El Bait Shop. Clear dark red, thin foamy white head, good retention. Aroma of raisin, caramel. Taste is raisin, toasted malt, toffee. Medium bodied, well balanced.
12oz bottle to tulip. Pours clear scotch brown, short tan head. Aroma of chocolate, caramel, molasses, sassafras, grains. Taste of same with tinge of nut, coffee and dark candi syrup. Super smooth.
12oz bottle to tulip. Pours clear scotch brown, shirt tan head. Aroma of chocolate, caramel, molasses, sassafras, grains. Taste of same with a tinge of coffee and dark candi syrup. Super smooth.

Aroma - syrupy kind of malt, a little toast, a touch of roast, and some birch like quality.
Appearance - the body is a clean dark amber, with good nucleation. The head is 2" and beige, and settles into a layer of filmy suds.
Taste - has a kind, slightly sweet syrupy malt. There is a slight toast and roast about the malt. There is a small hint of birch oil or sassafras, doubtful its in the batch, but it has that quality in place.
Palate - medium body, texture is velvety, the carbonation is average, the finish is slightly tannic.

Though with a slightly muted nose, the flavors are good, especially early on, when the maltiness stretches as far as caramel and chocolate, and it rounds into a solid breadiness. But the appearance signaled that it might be a bit flat (some early carbonation) and indeed, the palate just limped home rather disappointingly. O.k. enough in some ways, but nothing to recommend.
Nice dark amber color, aroma of caramel. Smooth, malty slight hint of hop bitterness. A very nice American version of the German Classic.
B. Pours a reddish brown color with khaki head. Hints of chocolate and coffee

[ bottle ][ 1.5oz ][ @Tasting ][ $? ][ mini snifter ][ 05.01.16 ]
translucent amber, thick cream head laces well. Simple honey-caramel nose, light oxidation. Thin, sticky bitter front palate, light papery bitterness. Super thin with low carbonation, dry end is barky.

12oz bottle. Medium beige head atop clear dark brown body. Aroma is moderately sweet, chocolate, caramel, some molasses, nutty. Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, some chocolate, nutty, light orange. Light-medium body, light stickiness.

Amber brown. Bottle says this is a black lager. Sweet, remind me of tasting malt extract. Malty. Really good. Caramel bomb. Another expensive "gift" from David. This one named same as the giraffe he gave me. I dig this....somewhat reminds me of non alcohol malty beverages I tried in Jamaica.
Bottle at the DC RateBeer Tasting. Clear amber with beige head. Aromas of caramel, toffee, biscuit. Tastes of caramel, toffee, dark fruit, light biscuit. Medium-light body with a dry finish.
12oz bottle pours a clear copper amber with some frothy, white head. Nose has pitted fruit, bread, caramel. Flavor is sweet, caramel, raisin, bread. Slick finish. Standard.
Bottle pour at the May 1st DC Tasting. Poured a clear red-amber color with a small white head. Aroma was light sweet malts, grain. Light toasted lager, roasted, malty crisp, sweet finish.
Bottle. Clear amber color, white head. Light caramel aroma. Burnt toast taste. OK.
From a bottle at the DC gathering May 1, 2016. Pours a clear mahogany with an off white head. Malty nose. Flavors of toasted grain. Decent. Nice for the style.

Exile, Gigi, draft. Burnt cigarettes. Or is that snuff? Maybe it's very dark chocolate. Or chocolate extract. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at the source. Deep ruby in color with lasting thin head. Aroma is Munich / European malts, (caramel, toffee, dried leaves). Flavor has a lighter body with the same rustic European malt bill. Lager yeast is found in the finish. Very robust for the style, lots of flavor. Very well crafted!
Tap at the brewpub. mahogany pour. nice nutty nose mixed with earth. tastes of hazelnuts, earthy, caramel, bitter pine. nice bodied and pleasant
Bottle. Pours dark mahogany with nice tan head. Nose and taste are toffee, caramel and nutty. Some roast in the aftertaste.
The best of the beers Jess and I tried at the brewery in 2015. Darkish brown, mildly sweet and near to no roastiness.

Out of the bottle. Very rich mahogany color with tan/white head. Tons of roasted nuttiness in aroma. Same in the taste with hazelnut and toffee notes. Crisp mouth feel and very clean flavors. Id put this up there as on of the best versions of a dunkel I have ever had. Hop profile is very minimal and faint. Some herbal but you really have to search your palate.
Tap at Exile. Dark amber pour with a white head. Lots of toast and hazelnut in this one. Clean. Mild toffee sweetness. Well made.

12 oz bottle from Hy-Vee Muscatine. Amber to brown and clear appearance with a small lasting head. Aroma of toffee, toasted grains, chocolate, nuts, dark malts, bread and light caramel. Similar flavor, mild bittersweet finish. Medium body. Good dunkel.

Pours a light mahogany. Aroma is caramel, dark caramel, earthy dirty nuts, sweet dough , maybe some herbal.Spice. Taste is bittersweet caramel, light nuts, a bit of herbal and some citrus. Similar to a brown ale almost, not bad for its percentage.

Clear chestnut pour with a thin off white head. Aroma is roasted nuts, lots of toast, some toffee, bread crust, medium caramel, herbal and grassy hops. Flavor is dry roasted nuts, browned flour, dark bread crust, light chocolate, toast and light herbal any spicy hops. Light body, slightly syrupy, but dry feel, light carbonation. Decent.
Aroma is toasted malts and wood. The flavor is toasted/dark malts, fruit, slight sweetness and a lightly tart finish.

Willbecher half liter draft at the brewery in Des Moines, Iowa. The pour is a hazed copper brown with a well formed ½ inch light tan head. The aroma soft cocoa malt sweet along with mineral and a faint roast character. The taste is clean cocoa notes along with a crisp dry finish which shows mineral. There is a nice hazelnut in the aftertaste. The palate is light bodied with crisp carbonation and the dry finish. Easy drinking, nice clean and fresh Dunkel.

on tap @ Exile Brewing / Des moines IA --- Opaque brown-black with a thin rim head, no lace. Taste is dark malt that grows in the palate adding a carbonation edge that carries through to the finish. Well-balanced, but standard German Dunkel.

Draft. Pours a dark amber color thin head. Aroma was mild and primarily malt - caramel, nut, toast. Medium sweet taste. Medium body, texture thin and a touch sticky, long mild bitter finish. Overall it was a pretty good dunkel would order again.

On tap at the brewpub. Comes reddish brown with a decent beige head. Aroma of malt, caramel, and fruit. Taste is malt, fruit, caramel, roast, and grass. Like all of Exiles beers, this one too was very well made. Very enjoyable.
Pours with a nice head which takes a while to dissipate. Great nutty flavor with a long finish. Served a little cold but flavored really opened up as the beer warmed up. Very drinkable beer.
Sampled on tap at Exile. Pours a brown color with white head. Malty, nutty aromas. Clean, nutty, malty, light roasty, toast flavors. Really good dunkel.

Tap @ Exile. Pours a touch hazy dark orange space with a cream colored head. Dry, nutty, caramel, toasty, herbal aroma. Really lovely, nutty, a touch smoky, caramel flavor. Ye gods, these fuckers know what theyre doing.
On tap at brewery.  Clear briwn pour..no head.. coffe taste and malts..taste is good i like it

Pours a deep reddish brown with a good long lasting head and nice lacing on the glass. 

The aroma is richly malty, very nutty, and lightly roasty. The beer is not overly sweet smelling and really very inviting. 

The flavor is nutty and not especially sweet but well within the sweetness level of the style, Im so used to Dunkel being on the edge of annoyingly sweet, and theyre many times really wonderful beers if they dont enter that territory, this one is on the drier side... so more to my taste for sure. There are some nice chocolate and roasty notes with most of the bitterness coming from a light herbal hoppiness. Very clean tasting, very well executed. 

Hopefully the style designation on this will get ironed out as this is not a  Dunkelweizen at all.... The commercial description tags it specifically as a Dunkel, which is what it is... and its a damn fine one at that.
on tap-offwhite-dk amber.  A-fruit, med malt.  T-med malt-caramel/chocolate, some fruit/grassy hops.  Soft carbonation.

Tap at brewpub. Deep brown brew with only traces of a light khaki head. The nose has some peanuts, caramel and sweet potatoes. The taste is roasted with some caramel and black tea notes. There is also some peanut character. The best one I had at Exile. A nice brew.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear, deep brown-amber colored body with a finger-width, creamy and frothy, light tan head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is nutty toffees with a light sweetness, some caramels, touches of toast, and a light herbal grass. Flavor is similar. Smooth, nutty toffees and caramels with a light sweetness up front before a touch of toast comes in with just a slight fruit note. Finishes clean and dry with a light grassy bitterness and a nice, clean malt backing. Fairly lengthy aftertaste following a smooth, medium body and a soft, moderate carbonation. Overall, a basic, but pretty well done Dunkel. Smooth, lightly sweetened malts with a touch of toast and a clean grassy bitterness. Very easy drinking. Nice beer.
